conclusion: Understanding the processes and properties of an ideal gas is necessary to compare internal energy at states a and c.
The diagram shows two adiabatic processes (curved lines) and two isochoric processes (vertical lines).
Adiabatic processes involve no heat exchange with surroundings (Q = 0). Isochoric processes have constant volume.
For an adiabatic process involving an ideal gas, PV^γ = constant, where γ is the adiabatic index.
The internal energy U of an ideal gas depends only on its temperature T: U = nC_vT.
To compare internal energies at states a and c, compare their temperatures.
In an adiabatic process, temperature change relates to volume change by TV^(γ-1) = constant.
State c is at a higher pressure and lower volume compared to state a.
Since the process from c to a is adiabatic, use TV^(γ-1) = constant.
At state c, the volume is lower than at state a. For adiabatic expansion (c to a), temperature decreases.
Temperature at state c is higher than at state a.
Internal energy U is proportional to temperature T. Since temperature at c is higher, internal energy at c is greater than at a.
The internal energy at state c is greater than the internal energy at state a.
